BE11:10am

Notably, the article emphasized KHC as a
potentially interested buyer, though frankly, we believe this potential divestiture is likely
to strike the interest of broader strategic as well as financial players.

BE11:10am

With respect to KHC, we believe an acquisition of Reckitt’s food portfolio makes clear
strategic and financial sense. First, we believe this asset largely consists of French’s
Mustard and Frank’s Red Hot Sauce, brands that complement KHC’s current
condiments portfolio (i.e. Heinz ketchup, Grey Poupon mustard), which could suggest a
potential for operational synergies, in our view. And, though we estimate that this
acquisition would prove only modestly accretive to KHC’s FY17E EPS (~+2% pro-forma
for estimated synergies, as per our analysis on page 3) given its relative size,
importantly, we do not believe this transaction would inhibit KHC’s appetite for a larger,
more transformative transaction

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Grey Poupon.

BE11:11am

That said, given the strong market share positions (by our math, French’s commands a
34% share and Frank’s Red Hot enjoys a 10% share of their respective categories) and
high margin profile of this asset (~30% profit margin in aggregate, by our estimate), we
would not be surprised if this potential divestiture garners a high level of interest across
the U.S. food group. With this in mind, we would note this asset complements MKC’s
flavor-oriented portfolio as well as CAG’s condiments business – with both companies
having stated a high degree of interest in M&A. Meanwhile, we believe the center-store
presence and high margin profile could also be highly appealing to PF, which has been
rather explicit about its desire to complete a transformative acquisition in the nearterm, in our view, and already possesses a very large shelf-stable business.

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,322, up 35.78 (+0.49%), High: 7,369, Low: 7,284, Volume: 189.66k

Goldman's counterparty to Liberty, so the idea was that Liberty must've raised.

PM11:13am

Have we ever properly understood what GS is doing in ITV??

11:13 am
PM11:13am

I havent

BE11:13am

Not entirely, other than lending out Liberty's stake.

BE11:14am

Which is what's going on here, I think. You'll remember the disclosure we noted earlier in the week about Liberty putting more stock on loan.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

I do

BE11:14am

I think, therefore, that it gets rehypothecated and Goldman appears to hold more.

BE11:15am

Except it doesn't. The underlying position hasn't changed. It's just that the votes are being double counted.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

You'll remember Dan did something on this irritating data quirk with regards Ocado.

BE11:15am

https://www.ft.com...-930f-061b01e23655

BE11:16am

I think the same applies to ITV. So anyone buying on Friday was making a bit of a mistake.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Liberum, however, argues that buying ITV is never a mistake.

BE11:17am

So they've repurposed Friday's news into a buy case. Sort of.

BE11:17am

A RNS statement from ITV stated that Goldman Sachs (acting on behalf of Liberty Global, which owns 9.9% of ITV) had gone above the 25% shareholding level, fueling a spike in the share price and speculation of a Liberty bid for ITV. Having spoken with ITV, it is saying that this is not Liberty increasing its stake but more to do with the way that Liberty holds its ITV stake with Goldmans and related to Liberty loaning out some stock to Goldmans, which in turn has lent out the stock causing the apparent spike in the stated shareholding. Obviously, there is a lack of transparency around these transactions and the timing of the RNS (on a Friday afternoon) also looks slightly odd.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The news last week is likely to fuel speculation that Liberty may be preparing a bid for ITV. Liberty Global’s recent comments have indicated that it is interested in expanding its exposure to TV advertising and it has bought Free to Air TV assets in Belgium and the Republic of Ireland (where it bought both TV3 and UTV Ireland, the latter off ITV). The latter exposure is particularly interesting given the obvious similarities between the UK and the ROI both in the FTA market and also with regards to Liberty’s position as the major Pay-TV operator in both countries. Moreover, Liberty has stated that it wants to expand its exposure to FTA TV and the UK market would be an obvious target given its cable assets in the UK, particularly as Liberty is expanding out its network via its Project Lightning programme.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Morgan Stanley.

BE11:22am

Apple represents, in our view, more than 40% of Imagination revenues and as
such represents the core profit generator of the company with which other
technologies are being designed. We believe the shares will fall significantly
today and our bear case is 140p. This is not the first time that Apple has dropped
a supplier unexpectedly – Portal Player, Sigmatel, CSR, Wolfson all suffered
from unexpected endings of customer relationships. There is a difference here
though – Imagination holds significant patents around graphics cores, in
particular those which allow lower power use, and is considering discussing
different commercial arrangements with Apple around those.

BE11:22am

IMG has a credit facility with HSBC that was breached in 2016 and later
renegotiated. We do not have insight in the new agreement but think it likely
involves property of the group. The previous conditions of the agreements
implied the company needed to keep a ND/EBITDA of less than 3x.
Net debt was £40.8m in Dec 2016 and we were forecasting total revenues of
£142m and EBIT (adj.) of £30m for full-year ending April 2017.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

FY17e figures:
- Apple royalty revs $71m
- Non-Apple royalty revs $75m
- Of the non-Apple revenues, $30m is MIPS, with current customer base including Mobileye and Spreadtrum

PM11:23am

That bear case looks historic no

PM11:23am

w

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Yes, very.

BE11:23am

The bear case it better set out by JP Morgan.

BE11:23am

The bear case is zero.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Apple is by far Imagination's most important customer and responsible for the majority of its revenue. The information that it will not use Imagination IP after next 15-24 months is potentially fatal for the company and the only rescue would be a distress sale. In fact, we think it virtually impossible to build a model for the company without Apple revenue. Thus though the fall in the stock post the announcement is substantial we find it difficult to value the company without Apple revenue and the company will likely have to effect a distress sale in the current environment. The options in front of the company include: 1) Sale of graphics IP to Apple. 2) Sale of right to use graphics IP to Apple while continuing to maintain its own graphics IP business to other customers along with its MIPS and Ensigma businesses. 3) Break up and sale of all the businesses of the company. Only the graphics IP would today get proper value, though breaking up the assets could potentially generate some more value than that reflected in the stock today after the announcement, though the cost will be in terms of how long this break up takes to execute.

BE11:24am

Now, what's mildly interesting here is the bid stuff leading up to this.

Go on

BE11:28am

Scenarios (1) and (2) - the status quo and the re-pricing
The first scenario would be Apple continues paying royalties at rates similar to history
which is the assumption behind our last published price target of 270p (now under
review). The second scenario would be the royalty rate is renegotiated lower. We
estimate that Apple currently pays IMG around c$0.30 royalty per device. In FY19E, as
long as any renegotiated royalty rate remains above $0.11 we estimate IMG would
remain profitable (before stock comp) under the current business plan (i.e. rising
investment in PowerVR and gaining other customers). Placing a value on this scenario is
tough but assuming $0.11 royalty rate and growth elsewhere to restore profitability (to
20%/30% EBIT margins long-term), our DCF model suggests a value of 90p/140p,
assuming all else being equal.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

There's no cash on the balance sheet to speak of to offer any sort of cushion?

BE11:29am

Why would they need cash!? I mean, they have one customer providing 50% of revenue at a near 100% margin!??!

BE11:29am

Scenario (3) - what if IMG is not successful
If IMG is not successful in generating revenue from Apple of some form longer-term,
we estimate the business would be loss-making by c£22m (before stock comp and
based on our assumptions still holding for the rest of the business) and would need to
investigate either: 1) the cost base; 2) gaining significant new business or 3) finding
another way to generate value from the IP (we note that the MIPS patent portfolio was
sold for $350m). Valuing this scenario is highly challenging in our view but positively
we estimate IMG reaches a net cash position by end of FY18E.

11:29 am

In order to be sustainable in the long run you have to be major first-tier international player. With almost 20,000 staff we have not reached an optimal stage. [...] In order to be sustainable in the long run you have to be major first-tier international player. With almost 20,000 staff we have not reached an optimal stage."

11:34 am

How did a company like CH2M Hill end up with a name like CH2M Hill?

BE11:34am

The kind of mergers where both sides have managements to keep happy, I imagine.

PM11:34am

Actually...

11:34 am
PM11:34am

CH2M was founded in 1946 in Corvallis, Oregon by Oregon State University civil engineering professor Fred Merryfield and three of his students: Holly Cornell, James Howland and Thomas Burke Hayes (the firm was named after the founders, with Howland and Hayes making up the H2 portion).[5] Cornell, Howland, and Hayes were all graduates of Oregon State University.[6] The company became CH2M Hill name after a 1971 merger with Clair A. Hill and Associates of Redding, California.[7] The firm remained headquartered in Oregon until 1980, when a decision was made to relocate to Colorado, a more central location in the United States.

BE11:35am

Well, there we have it.

BE11:36am

So anyway, we seem to be in the position where shares are up on a market rumour of M&A activity that people are treating as credible .....

11:37 am

PM11:40am

11:40 am
PM11:40am

Readers with a long memory will be well aware that when currency volatility hits South Africa then the results can be spectacular. The collapses of mid-1998, late 2001, late 2008 and the end of 2015 all served as warnings of how narrow the exit door can prove to be when investors choose to flee the ZAR. This, of course, is an almost perfect example of what happens when a carry trade target currency collapses.

PM11:41am

Given this it could be argued that the typically substantial 1-year yield differential between South Africa and the US (an average of 6.8 percentage points since October 1995) has not proved that supportive for the currency, especially when it is remembered that the USD has, on average, gained 8% a year over the same period. However, this crude statistic masks the fact that there were two substantial lengths of time (October 2002 to May 2005 and July 2009 to September 2011) during this twenty year time span when the carry trade worked extremely well. Indeed the average year on year gain (from currency appreciation and yield pick-up combined) from holding ZAR over the USD over these two periods was an attractive 15%. The corollary to this, however, is that during the primary downtrends for the ZAR the USD was gaining an average of 15% a year, easily overwhelming any potential yield advantage.

PM11:41am

There are, of course, complicating domestic factors that have fed into a rise in volatility of late. However, it should also be noted that historical volatility in the ZAR has been trending lower since the summer of 2016 and has coincided with a broader decline for the FX markets. Moreover, the current level of 21 day historical volatility (measured on an open high low close basis) stands at a relatively modest 18%, which compares to an average level for the past decade of (20%). In other words there is nothing particularly untoward about the price action at present despite the recent political turmoil. With the one-year yield differential (6%) well under the average for the past twenty two years (6.77%) the opportunity for a particularly sharp move to emerge is certainly there.

11:41 am
PM11:42am

So while some people saying 'nothing to see here, move along' -- Derrick is saying do be careful

THE boss of embattled Kurdish oil producer Gulf Keystone has brushed off speculation that it remains a takeover target as he prepares to present the company's $500m (£399m) turnaround plan to investors this week. The company, once a darling of retail investors, was rumoured to be the target of takeover interest from Chinese oil major Sinopec at the end of last year after emerging from a financial restructuring with a stronger balance sheet. The company was also linked to Kurdish peer DNO while it hunted for a willing buyer to avoid the painful financial overhaul.

BE11:50am

Initiating coverage on Brewin Dolphin with Overweight (PT 360p), Rathbone Brothers with Equal Weight (PT 2300p): We expand our coverage of the Asset/ Wealth Managers with initiations on Brewin Dolphin and Rathbone Brothers. While we are positive in our outlook for the Wealth Management industry in the medium term and think both names are positively positioned within it, we express preference for Brewins over Rathbones. This is due to more focused growth initiatives, visibility on delivering these, better flow momentum and a stronger and more transparent balance sheet. Further, we think Brewins offers good value at only ~15x 2017E PE. Rathbones, on the other hand, has already outperformed the market YTD (+19% vs. the FSTE AllShare +3.5%) and valuation looks full in our opinion at 18.5x 2017E PE.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Stronger flow momentum at Brewins: The recent industry flow environment has been difficult due to market uncertainty and investor caution. Despite this backdrop both Brewins and Rathbones attracted net inflows in 2016. However we think outlook is slightly better for Brewins, which reported Investment Management flows at an annualised rate of ~7% for the qtr-to-Dec 16 vs. Rathbone Brothers reporting an organic flow rate of 2.9% within Investment Management for 2016. Brewins’ initiatives to boost growth through direct distribution, targeting the intermediary channel, particularly through its Model Portfolio Service (MPS) and Professional Services, and increasing brand awareness appear more focused and we are seeing the benefits of them coming through in flow momentum.

BE11:51am

Rathbones’ operating margin amongst best in class, but Brewins’ margin on upward trajectory: Rathbones has historically shown good operating efficiency with margins of ~29-30%, but we think it is Brewins which has a margin improvement story. While Brewins has now largely completed investment spend following its strategic review,

BE11:51am

Rathbones still has more to come. Brewins reported operating margin of 21.6% at FY16 and we forecast this to improve to 24.5% by 2019E, in line with management guidance. Rathbones, on the other hand, recorded an operating margin of 29.8% at FY16 and we expect this to remain flattish going forward.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Brewins offers better yield ~4% and more attractive valuation: Brewins has a higher relative dividend yield at ~4% (77% payout ratio at FY16) vs. Rathbones at ~2.5% (47% payout ratio at FY16). We also think Brewins offers an attractive entry point trading at only 14.8x 2017E PE, below peer group average ~16.8x and its historical avg ~15.5x.

BE11:52am

The Rathbones share has already risen 19% YTD vs. the FTSE AllShare +3.5% and BRW
flat and we think valuation looks full.

Brewin Dolphin Holdings PLC (BRW:LSE): Last: 312.10, down 0.3 (-0.10%), High: 317.10, Low: 311.90, Volume: 148.51k
11:52 am

11:53 am
PM11:54am

Event: The ZAR has fallen sharply in recent days on news that President Jacob Zuma has reshuffled his Cabinet and removed Pravin Gordhan as finance minister. Gordhan was well regarded by markets and our economists see this as a potential move by Zuma to push for ‘radical economic transformation’ and increased public spending. They believe this could lead to a downgrade of SA to sub-investment grade by the credit rating agencies and have a 12 month target for the ZAR of over 14 (spot ~13.4), however, a re-testing of the extreme weakness seen in early 2016 seems unlikely given the broader recovery in the global economy

PM11:54am

Mining implications: 2017 promises to be a news-flow heavy year in SA. The ANC National Policy Conference is in June ahead of the National Conference in December. By year end the market should have greater clarity around the potential successor to Zuma, who is expected to step down as President ahead of national elections in Q219. The revised Mining Charter could also be released in Q217, but has faced multiple delays. Greater certainty around future leadership and mining policy will be a positive step. However, a key element of the mining charter around "once empowered always empowered" is being disputed in the courts and, while there is no set time frame, it is our expectation that this stretches beyond 2017

PM11:54am

Weak ZAR impact: With ~45% of group EBITDA from SA based assets, the ZAR is Anglo’s largest sensitivity with a 10% move impacting EBITDA by ~5% on our estimates. In isolation, it is tempting to view the weakness as positive (lower costs in US$ terms), however, history shows (see charts within) that a weak ZAR usually leads to underperformance of Anglo in absolute and relative (to the mining sector) terms

BE11:59am

Treasure Beach is a 4-star, 35-room hotel in Paynes Bay, in the parish of St. James in Barbados. It is the adjoining property to Elegant Hotels' Tamarind hotel, which in turn is situated next to Daphne's and The House, which are also owned by the Group. As a result, the acquisition will mean that four of Elegant Hotels' properties will account for a continuous 300 metre stretch of the prestigious west coast, or "Platinum Coast", of Barbados. Treasure Beach occupies around 1.18 acres of land, and its amenities include a swimming pool, spa, and restaurant.
